CONCLUSION: Violation of Art. 6-1;Remainder inadmissible;Pecuniary damage - claim dismissed
JUDGES: Anatoly Kovler;Julia Laffranque;Khanlar Hajiyev;Linos-Alexandre Sicilianos;Mirjana Lazarova Trajkovska;Peer Lorenzen
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in GPE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the Government of GPE appointed the applicant Head of ORG with effect from DATE .

CARDINAL . Meanwhile , on DATE the applicant ’s neighbour PERSON filed a criminal complaint against him with the police authorities in GPE . She alleged that on DATE the applicant had demolished a separating wall erected between their backyards by her husband and broken one of the windows of her house . In her statement of CARDINAL DATE , PERSON added that during the incident of DATE the applicant had also shouted that she and her family should come out so that he could kill them .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG Attorney ’s ORG ( Općinsko državno odvjetništvo u GPE ) indicted the applicant before ORG ( PERSON ) accusing him of the criminal offences of uttering threats and damaging another ’s property , and invited the court to issue a penal order in accordance with section CARDINAL of LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE a single judge of ORG issued a penal order ( kazneni nalog ) against the applicant under section CARDINAL of LAW , finding him guilty as charged and imposing a prison sentence of DATE , suspended for DATE . The applicant was not informed of , and did not participate in , those proceedings . The order was served on the applicant on DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant lodged an objection ( prigovor ) against the penal order arguing that he had not committed the criminal offences for which he had been convicted , and that he had not been given an opportunity to defend himself and present evidence .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG set aside its penal order of DATE and dropped the charges against the applicant under section CARDINAL of LAW without any further explanation .

CARDINAL . Meanwhile , by a decision of DATE the Government of GPE removed the applicant from his position as Head of ORG on the grounds that he had been found guilty of a criminal offence by the judgment of ORG of DATE . The decision reads as follows :
D E C I S I O N
“ PERSON is hereby relieved of his duties as Head of ORG .
R e a s o n s

Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of ORG provides that the heads of the regional offices of the ORG administration are appointed and removed by the Government of GPE upon a proposal of the ORG secretary of ORG on the basis of a previously conducted public competition .
By a decision of the Government of GPE ... of CARDINAL DATE PERSON was appointed Head of ORG .

By judgment no . K CARDINAL/CARDINAL of ORG of DATE , PERSON was found guilty of a criminal offence against the rights and freedoms of man and the citizen defined in LAW and classified as uttering threats , in conjunction with a criminal offence against property defined in LAW and classified as damaging another ’s property . [ As a consequence , he ] received ... a prison sentence of DATE and DATE , suspended for DATE .
Having regard to foregoing , the ORG secretary of ORG considered that keeping PERSON as Head of ORG could harm the probity of the civil service .
In accordance with the above , the ORG secretary of ORG proposed that the Government of GPE relieve PERSON of his duties as Head of ORG . ORG accepted this proposal .
That being so , it was decided as indicated in the operative part . ”
The operative part of the decision was published in ORG no . CARDINAL of DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the DATE newspaper ORG PERSON reporting from the ORG ’s meeting of DATE , reported on the applicant ’s removal from office . A small article entitled “ Removals and appointments [ NORP i imenovanja ] ” in its relevant part read as follows :

“ In GPE the Government relieved PERSON , the incumbent Head of ORG , of his duties . ... PERSON was relieved of his duties because of a non - final judgment imposing a ... prison sentence of DATE and DATE , suspended for DATE , for a criminal offence against a freedom of man . ”

CARDINAL . On DATE the same daily published an article entitled “ Removed because of a non - existent ‘ judgment’ [ Smijenjen zbog nepostojeće presude ] ? ” , which described the circumstances surrounding the applicant ’s removal from office and gave him the opportunity to present his view .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant brought an administrative action in ORG against the Government of GPE challenging the decision on his removal .
CARDINAL . On DATE the Government of GPE submitted their reply to the applicant ’s action . That reply was not forwarded to the applicant . The relevant part of ORG reply read as follows :

“ ... The decision which is the subject of this administrative dispute does not disclose any breach of law raised by the plaintiff . The decision to relieve PERSON of his duties as Head of ORG was adopted in accordance with section PERSON ) of ORG . ...

It is undisputed that , by judgment no . K CARDINAL/CARDINAL of ORG of DATE , PERSON was found guilty of a criminal offence against the rights and freedoms of man and the citizen – uttering threats – defined in LAW , in conjunction with a criminal offence against property – damaging another ’s property – defined in LAW , and that he received ... a prison sentence of DATE and DATE , suspended for DATE .

The plaintiff argues that the present case concerns a penal order issued in accordance with section [ CARDINAL ] of LAW , to which he objected within the statutory time - limit , and that therefore there is no final judgment [ against him ] which could constitute an impediment to recruitment to the civil service set out in LAW .

However , the plaintiff ignores the fact that his removal from office was not owing to the existence of impediments to recruitment to the civil service set out in section CARDINAL of LAW . The discovery that , at the time of recruitment to the civil service or at the time of appointment to the position of Head of ORG , an impediment set out in section CARDINAL of LAW had existed , would have resulted in the termination of employment in the civil service by operation of law , pursuant to section CARDINAL ... of LAW . However , the present case does not concern such circumstances or the termination of employment in the civil service . Rather , [ it concerns ] the plaintiff ’s removal from his position as Head of ORG ... , where the impugned decision is not based on impediments to recruitment to the civil service but on circumstances concerning the plaintiff which were considered liable to ... harm the probity of ORG and the entire civil service . Criminal proceedings pending against a head of a ORG administration office may give a negative impression to the public and arouse suspicion as regards the diligent and lawful conduct of those employed in the ORG administration office run by such a person .
The plaintiff contests the right of the Government of GPE to remove a head of [ a ORG administration ] office at their own discretion ...

Contrary to the plaintiff ’s argument , we consider that the Government of GPE are entitled to remove a head of a ORG administration office at their own discretion because that is undoubtedly provided for by section CARDINAL of ORG . ...

Given that the contested decision was adopted in the procedure and in the manner prescribed by law , and that grounds ... for quashing or declaring [ it ] null and void do not exist , we propose that ORG dismiss the action as unfounded . ”

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed the applicant ’s action finding that the contested decision of CARDINAL March CARDINAL had been based on section CARDINAL ) of ORG ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) and section GPE ) of ORG ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) . The relevant part of ORG judgment reads as follows :
“ ... the said laws indisputably show that the Government of GPE ... are entitled to remove a head of a ORG administration office ... at their own discretion ...

... in the reasoning for their decision , the defendant authority [ that is , the Government of GPE ] ... stated the circumstances which influenced that decision . In particular , having regard to the complaints submitted about the plaintiff ’s work , and the fact that criminal proceedings are pending against him before ORG ... for a criminal offence against the rights and freedoms of man and the citizen ( the criminal offence of uttering threats defined in LAW ) , in conjunction with a criminal offence against property ( the criminal offence of damaging another ’s property defined in LAW ) , the ORG secretary of ORG in its proposal ... of DATE considered that the plaintiff should be relieved of [ his ] duties as Head of ORG because keeping him in that position could harm the probity of the civil service . That proposal was accepted by the defendant authority which , at the session held on DATE , adopted a decision on his removal . Contrary to the plaintiff ’s arguments , by doing so [ the defendant authority ] did not examine ... whether his [ career in the ] civil service should be terminated pursuant to section CARDINAL of LAW , in which case it should be taken into account whether or not a civil servant had been convicted by a final judgment of a criminal offence against the rights and freedoms of man and the citizen . However , pending criminal proceedings for such a criminal offence , or even the adoption of a non - final judgment , may , given the position of the head of a ORG administration office , harm the probity of the office run by such a person and the entire civil service . Namely , the conduct of the plaintiff which led to the institution of those criminal proceedings , and its negative connotations in the public perspective , harms his personal reputation and may arouse suspicion among citizens as regards the diligent and lawful operation of the ORG administration office run by such a person . ”

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant lodged a constitutional complaint against ORG judgment alleging violations of , inter alia , his constitutional rights to a fair hearing , presumption of innocence , and respect for his dignity , reputation and honour . He argued that he had been removed from office on the basis of a non - final conviction secured in criminal proceedings of which he had not been aware and in which he had not had the opportunity to participate .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ( Ustavni sud PERSON ) dismissed the applicant ’s complaint and served its decision on him on DATE . The relevant part of that decision reads as follows :

“ The complainant further alleges a violation of LAW which provides that everyone shall be [ presumed ] innocent and no one may consider him guilty of a criminal offence until his guilt has been established by a final court judgement .

The contested judgment was not delivered in proceedings in which the complainant ’s guilt was being determined , but [ in proceedings ] where the lawfulness of [ an ] administrative decision ... was examined .
The Constitutional Court therefore finds that the complainant ’s [ right ] provided for in LAW has not been breached by the contested judgment .
The complainant also alleges a violation of LAW , which guarantees to everyone respect for , and legal protection of , his personal and family life , dignity , reputation and honour .

The Constitutional Court finds that the complainant ’s [ right ] provided for in LAW had not been breached by the contested judgment because that judgment and the prior decision were rendered in lawfully conducted proceedings and are based on relevant legislation . ”

CARDINAL . LAW ( Zakon o državnim službenicima i namještenicima , Official Gazette no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) was in force DATE and DATE .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) set out impediments to recruitment to the civil service and provided that such an impediment existed in respect of a person who had been convicted by a final judgment for , inter alia , a criminal offence against the rights and freedoms of man and the citizen , or a criminal offence against property .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL provided that a civil servant ’s employment was to be terminated by operation of law , inter alia , when the judgment by which he or she had been convicted for a criminal offence referred to in section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of the same Act became final , or when it was discovered that an impediment referred to in the same section had existed at the time of recruitment .

CARDINAL . Sections CARDINAL of LAW ( Zakon o upravnim sporovima , ORG of ORG no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , and ORG nos . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , CARDINAL/CARDINAL and DATE ) provide for the remedy of reopening of proceedings before ORG and regulate the procedure following a petition for reopening . In particular , section CARDINAL reads as follows :
“ Proceedings ... shall be reopened upon a petition by a party :

CARDINAL ) if the party learns of new facts or discovers , or gains the opportunity to use , new evidence on the basis of which the dispute would have been resolved more favourably for him or her had these facts or evidence been presented or used in the previous court proceedings ;
CARDINAL ) if the decision was based on a judgement rendered in a criminal or civil case and that judgement was later set aside by another final court decision ;

A reopening shall be allowed on the grounds set forth in subsections ( CARDINAL ) and ( CARDINAL ) of this section , only if the party was unable , through no fault of his or her own , to raise these grounds in the previous proceedings . ”

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL provides that if LAW does not contain specific provisions on procedure before ORG ( that is , in administrative disputes ) , the provisions of LAW should apply mutatis mutandis .
